problem_text:
Is it true that large growth implies non-amenability? More precisely, consider a number ϵ > 0, an integer k ⩾ 2, a group Γ generated by a set S of k elements, and the corresponding exponential growth rate ω(Γ, S) defined as in 14.7. For ϵ small enough, does the inequality ω(Γ, S) ⩾ 2k − 1 − ϵ imply that Γ is non-amenable?
If ω(Γ, S) = 2k − 1, it is easy to show that Γ is free on S, and in particular non-amenable; see Section 2 in (R. I. Grigorchuk, P. de la Harpe, J. Dynam. Control Syst., 3, no. 1 (1997), 51–89).
P. de la Harpe
answer: No, it does not. Counterexamples can be found even in the classes of abelian-by-nilpotent and metabelian-by-finite groups. (G. N. Arzhantseva, V. S. Guba, L. Guyot, J. Group Theory, 8 (2005), 389–394).
